data.title: Vehicle physics is broken with current Godot.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux, but seems unrelated

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Setup a car using the same parameters as in truck town demo.
Don't add collision shape. Use y-offset of 0 for the wheels from body, and setup
every wheel parameter to the same configuration as in demo.
Don't add collision shape yet, test your car - it should be stable on flat ground,
no jumping, just stationary.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Add collision shape (I used Box). The expected outcome is nothing changed in car behavior.
Actually, car starts to vibrate at high pitch rate. Delete collision shape - nothing changes, still vibrating and jumping around surface. The only way out is delete scene and start anew.
Not adding collision shape avoids this bug, but everything passes through your car then.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Will add if nobody can reproduce this.

It seems that other tweaking of parameters lead tho this problem, but it is quite random and unrelated,
as returning to known set won't fix it and problem still persists.

Video, demonstrating this bug: https://youtu.be/IzwvcN0Jbo0

data.title: Wrong elements size after changing default editor font.
data.body:
Windows 7 x64
Godot v2.0.1 stable.official

Size of window elements in some dialogs looks wrong after changing default Text Editor font and Global font to Times New Roman, 16 pt.

![bug1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12411232/14060298/de9715c4-f370-11e5-964a-c59fafe3b1aa.png)

Probably, because of this I can't click buttons Find and Cancel in the Search window, though they could be accessable with Tab.

![bug2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12411232/14060304/1c553774-f371-11e5-8020-b7107e15df3f.png)

data.title: Screen size settings in Android exporting options do not affect the resulted apk
data.body:
**Operating system or device:** Ubuntu 15.04, 64 bit, Godot v2.0 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Screen size settings in Android exporting options do not affect the resulted apk. Regardless the settings Google Play Developers console informs that _small, normal, xlarge_ screens are supported. It always omit _large_ screen.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Un-check all the screen sizes in Android export options, export release template and upload it to Google Play Developer Console.

data.title: CanvasItem.draw_line() width depends on display resolution
data.body:
When drawing lines in Node2D using `draw_line()` function, the line width seems to be in display pixels instead of node coordinates.

Line drawn with same width looks a lot wider on low DPI desktop than on high DPI Android device. Positions of lines work as expected.

I can fix this by multiplying the line width by `get_viewport_transform().get_scale().x`, but shouldn't the function take the line width in same units as the positions?

When connecting item_selected to a function it fires that function twice

**Steps to reproduce:**

Connect tree to function, it will fire twice

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Stereoscopic camera support - for google cardboard apps
data.body:
Adding a Stereoscopic camera node to godot would allow developers to create google cardboard apps for the android and iOS app stores.

Currently godot is also missing support for gyroscope input. I filed that as a separate issue, since gyro has application in a wider spectrum of apps - not only vr/ar.
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4138

A stereoscopic camera simply splits the device screen into two screens - one for the left and one for the right eyes. The user can then put their mobile device into a google cardboard unit (costs 5$ on ebay) and use it as a VR headset. With some of the later models with better screen users can really get an experience closer to the more expensive headsets (oculus and vive).

My guess is that this is already becoming the widest spread form of vr experience because of it's low entry price tag. So supporting it in godot will open the engine to a new and vibrant market that is not saturated yet.
https://play.google.com/store/apps/collection/promotion_3001011_cardboard_featured_apps?hl=en

here is google's official plugin reference:
https://developers.google.com/cardboard/unity/reference#package_contents

data.title: Support localization of scancode strings
data.body: Currently there's no way to get a localized version of OS.get_scancode_string, it would be great if this was possible.

data.title: Export/ImageGroup: the problem with the same name in atlases
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Win10, Android 5.1 (Jiayu s3)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I created a group (Atlas) for units and received a strange result. In version 1.1, this was not.
It should be like this:
![godot_v2 2016-03-25 03-34-55-47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/233268/14035150/f372f520-f23b-11e5-8451-5623cc71e35a.jpg)

and it turns out like this:
![prj_x_32 2016-03-25 03-35-22-57](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/233268/14035172/28984354-f23c-11e5-9022-18af41fc7a35.jpg)

How to accurately reproduce this problem, I do not know yet. I have another atlas with icons and interface with it all right. In the near future I will try to provide more detailed information.

PS
This is a different story in the performance somehow low enough for 100 units. And I do not understand what it is connected. Because I disabled all the animation almost all processes. You're a couple who can not so much influence the speed. :(

data.title: Add Input.get_gyroscope to godot, it is NOT the same as accelerometers!
data.body:
I've been trying to do something akin to
https://alastaira.wordpress.com/2013/08/24/the-7dfps-game-jam-augmented-reality-and-spectral-echoes/

or this:
http://blog.heyworks.com/how-to-write-gyroscope-controller-with-unity3d/

even youtube and facebook now supports this feature - you can view 360 degree videos using your phone's gyroscope:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aQd41nbQM-U
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f-7qq8n2iqw
http://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/youtube-360-degree-videos-look-great/

I thought that this would be an interesting game mechanic and indeed it has been used in a nintendo 3ds game:
https://youtu.be/vX44AVkwFmc?t=2m11s

So i tried to implement it in gdscript only to find that it is impossible to get any good results with the accelerometer alone. Unity on the other hand does have access to the device's gyroscope and most implementations use the gyroscope to do that.

There is a difference in what this sensor does - it is not the same as accelerometer:
http://www.livescience.com/40103-accelerometer-vs-gyroscope.html
Almost every tablet device and phone has a gyro. It is becoming more and more relevant with the boom of VR and AR devices too. I just think that there is a missed opportunity for godot here.

Is gyro input on the roadmap? Are devs interested in implementing it at some point? If so, this would be complimentary to another feature - to support google cardboard/vr camera. :)
A google cardboard unit costs 5$ on ebay and turns most smartphones into a cheap vr headset.

data.title: Key release event not sent if the key is released too quickly
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If you press and release a key quickly enough, Godot will never send the release event, making the game believe that you're still pressing the key, even though that's not true. The action needed to trigger this is not too common to perform in any game, but a nervous player can trigger this experiencing a bad, annoying glitch. They keys needs to be pressed and released again, so the game finally sends a release event for that key.

Video proof:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5v_IRHfDg90

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Run the Godot's demo "Platformer" game
2. Tap the right arrow key to get the character going right, however tap it as quickly and swiftly as you can, just bounce off that key, putting minimal weight on it, putting all your effort into speed, not force. More like you'd tap on a djembe drum membrane than type on a keyboard.
3. Watch the character lock on walking right, like the key is still being held.

data.title: Per-light semi-dynamic lightmaps?
data.body:
In the good old Unreal I the first scene demonstrates very well this feature.

Take a look at all the blinking lights around - they all are using lightmaps, but the lighmaps seem to be individual for every light and mixed in realtime allowing per-light changes, like flickering just one of the lights without dimming the rest, and of course - still using baked shadows and stuff. Dynamic lights are only used for moving objects like projectiles and explosions in this game (and they don't cast any shadows).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Op-tys_98Ek

Can this be achieved with Godot?

data.title: Do not show black margins when stretch_aspect=keep
data.body:
_Bugsquad edit: removed mention to #1136 being fixed based on later comment_

If user set stretch_aspect=keep, then godot will keep both width and height of viewport and will not clip it.

data.title: Window Dialogs Don't Show
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Just last night I got Window Dialogs to show, but today they won't. Only thing that has changed is that I moved the Godot executable to /usr/bin last night. Today I opened the project and the windows don't show when running. They show in edit mode, though. Clicking the visibility (eye icon) does nothing to show it. I have to add a script to the window and add.. 

`func _init(): 
    show()` 

for it to show. (show() should be indented on the next line in that statement but I couldn't get it to work on github.
[WindowTest.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/186594/WindowTest.tar.gz)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a Window Dialog, any kind and it won't show on my system.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Templates for the most basic GDscripts.
data.body:
**This is a feature proposal which would improve the first experience with Godot for new useres.**

I think it would be a really great feature if you could choose between different templates when you create a new GDscript. Like in blender where you can choose between many basic script structures: for example "Gamelogic module", "UI simple"...
The default template (`func _ready():`  ...) should stay of course.
This could be embedded into the create new script dialog box like so:
![godot_templeate proposal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16718859/13988773/b5a813c6-f10d-11e5-9ffa-3955def15eca.png)

There should be a lot of,  unnecessary examples with too many comments (that sound strange ;). This should help beginners to get their interactive "game" up and running in about 2 min with no experience! And if there is a big catalog of small to 50 line templates than also experienced unseres can learn from it (especially when there are a lot of comments). 
In addition to beginnerfrendliness this can speed up some peoples work speed with scripts like: "W,A,S,D 3Drigid body controller" or "3D fps camera only".

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer.  Unable to get the position of animation.
data.body: The AnimationTreePlayer node is missing tool receiving position animation.

data.title: Expose data about exact graphics API
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Any with questionable OpenGL support.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It is hard to debug Godot driver issues, because Godot doesn't expose any information about required graphics API, see
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4079#issuecomment-197876319
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4079#issuecomment-198079545

Expected that engine could at least output all OpenGL API functions that are linked in the code. Then some script could use that list to show minimal compatible OpenGL version. Then https://piglit.freedesktop.org/ tests could be run to see what exactly is missing from target OpenGL API to match needed requirements.

When this mechanism is in place, it can also be used to detect which specific graphics API is needed by specific game and lower its hardware requirements.

Graphics API requirements can also be tracked in CI scripts to ensure that they don't climb up from certain standard.

This is a prerequisite for #1162.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Run Godot under QEMU?

data.title: Replacing WindowDialog with another node leaves behind "x" button
data.body:
godot 2.0.1 stable

If you create a WindowDialog node then replace it with any other node, the new node will keep drawing the "x" button that the windowdialog created. It seems to be anchored to the new node as well.

data.title: Add ByteArray
Scene files changing in unexpected way after saving
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Arch Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It appears that whenever I save a scene file in the editor(so far tested with TSCN and XML formats) in addition to whatever changes I make, additional changes are introduced, and this happens even if I don't make any changes myself. The changes seem to be related to sub_resources, e.g., their IDs get switched and occur all over the file. This complicates committing changes to scenes in an SCM system, making it a choice between making a messy commit or sorting what was intentional change and what wasn't each time. 
If it's an intended feature, there should be a way to disable it, or at at least a way to diff the scene while ignoring these changes should be provided.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Seems to occur with scenes that have multiple nodes and resources. It's enough to just open the scene and immediately save it in the editor. The scene file registers as changed after that. Tested on v.2.0.1

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
 Can be reproduced with the [platformer demo](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/tree/master/demos/2d/platformer).
Sample diffs of the occurring changes on a scene from my project and from the platformer demo:
https://gist.github.com/Srogozins/f867df7c60c5bcfe3790

data.title: Android crash on scene loading with relative path
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Android 4.0.3 ;  LG P700

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When some scenes are loaded by script, the Android app crashes on startup. The phone must be rebooted. 
- If you run only the scene it works nice also on Android. 
- If you instance the scene by editor the app works nice too.
- It crashes only if the scene is loaded in a script.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Click on the example project link. (wait a minute hubiC seems slow on my Firefox)
- Check the zip file and download it. The poisoned scene is "PausePopup2.tscn"
- Connect an Android device.
- Run the project on Android.
- Epileptic persons should switchoff the device immediately.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

 http://ovh.to/KsqY4Xb

data.title: Tilemap drawing shortcuts for whole cols and rows
data.body:
I would like to suggest a feature for the tilemap drawing functionality.
It would be great to draw whole rows or columns by marking the start point while holding shift key and then the endpoint. Then the tiles between those points get painted. 
Also it would be great if we could fill a previous made selection.

data.title: Function syntax highlighting
data.body: Added syntax highlighting for functions and function calls. It does not change the highlighting of the built in functions such as yield, rand_range, ceil ect.

data.title: 3D armature import is broken
data.body:
The only case for 3D import for armatured animated meshes now is:
The tested revision is a895e2e372c9df2a9972f38134ae0ea9c8bf45a8
1. No mechanism bones in scene, no non-deforms in scene and no IK setups.
2. No morph targets on armatured meshes.

Any added detail breaks animations and produce distorted meshes or meshes fail to import.

data.title: Fix GDScript crash when call show/hide in func _exit_tree
Editor is blinking when saving a script
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

When I save a script with CTRL+S, the text editor blinks, showing the current scene for a few milliseconds + a progress bar popup.
This is annoying, because I use this shortcut as frequently as an end-of-line, the editor flashes a lot.

data.title: EditorData: Add plugins in front to allow overriding plugins
data.body:
Currently, new plugins are being added to the back so it is not possible to create a plugin to handle a object that already has a built-in plugin. Example:

``` GDScript
tool
extends EditorPlugin

func handles(object):
    # Suppossing my_custom_sprite_node.gd extends Sprite
    # This is never called since SpriteRegionEditorPlugin already edits Sprite
    return object extends preload("my_custom_sprite_node.gd")
```

Adding the plugins in front fixes that, though I am not sure what's the addition order for GDScript plugins. Maybe a _get_priority()_ method that could be overridden to sort _editor_plugins_ would be a better idea.
